title: Social Responsibility Practice Through Interior Design Education: Case Study Based on Scientific Inquiry·Variable Control·Simulation

context.prior_knowledge: Basic interior design theory and practical experience, foundational VR simulation skills, and introductory understanding of scientific inquiry methodologies (observation, hypothesis formulation, variable control, data analysis)
context.additional_context: Conducted in a VR-simulated environment replicating real low-income community cases, this team-based project involves experimental design, quantitative data measurement, and scientific analysis to develop evidence-based design solutions. Metrics include spatial efficiency, user satisfaction, and cultural appropriateness.

learning_goals: Learners create an interior design plan considering community context and quantitatively analyze spatial efficiency using scientific observation methods and variable control.

Within one week, learners propose two communication strategies for conflict resolution and consensus-building in a collaborative simulation involving three residents and two NGO representatives. They receive "Effective" or higher feedback from four out of five peer evaluators. Throughout the process, they apply variable control and evidence-based approaches in experimental design to make data-driven decisions.

Learners can propose spatial design solutions reflecting cultural sensitivity and receive evaluations through scientific analysis based on experimental data (user feedback, spatial efficiency metrics).

resources: Bahrain community development case study database

difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
